Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common.collection

Class SynchronizedWiredList<E>

java.lang.Object
nl.naturalis.common.collection.SynchronizedWiredList<E>
Type Parameters:
E - The type of the elements in the list
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<E>, Collection<E>, List<E>
public final class SynchronizedWiredList<E> extends Object implements List<E>

A decorator for the WiredList class that you can use when multiple threads will be updating a WiredList concurrently. A SynchronizedWiredList ensures proper synchronization and then forwards to an internally managed WiredList.

Read-intensive vs. Write-intensive Usage

When instantiating a SynchronizedWiredList, you can choose whether it is for read-intensive use or for write-intensive use. Write-intensive use means you expect the number of writes (or writer threads) to be comparable to the number of reads (or reader threads). Read-intensive use means you expect the number of reads to be substantially higher than the number of writes, and you expect the list to become large. If not both conditions are met, opt for write-intensive usage, as the locking strategy used for read-intensive usage is itself relatively costly.

Fluent API

SynchronizedWiredList preserves the fluent API of WiredList. However, if you repeatedly compose long call chains using the fluent API, you are probably better off using WiredList itself and manually synchronize around the entire call chain.

See Also:
  • ReentrantLock
  • ReentrantReadWriteLock

    • exclusiveWiredIterator

      public WiredIterator<E> exclusiveWiredIterator(boolean reverse)

      Returns a WiredIterator that will prevent other threads from updating the list while the iteration is in progress. This method has an advantage over manual synchronization when the list was created for read-intensive use (see class comments). In that case other threads can keep reading from the list while the iteration is in progress.

      Note that the WiredIterator interface not only extends Iterator but also AutoCloseable. When obtaining a WiredIterator through this method, you SHOULD ALWAYS do so using a try-with-resources block. The close method will release the Lock acquired at the start of the iteration. If you don't call the close method, the lock will still be properly released, but this will only happen once the iterator gets garbage-collected. (NB it is unnecessary to start a try-with-resources block when obtaining a WiredIterator in any other way.) 

      
 SynchronizedWiredList<String> swl = new SynchronizedWiredList<>();
 // add some elements ...
 try(WiredIterator<E> itr = swl.wiredIterator(false)) {
  while(itr.hasNext()) {
    // do stuff ...
  }
 }
      Parameters:
      reverse - Whether to traverse the list backwards
      Returns:
      A WiredIterator that traverses the list from the first element to the last, or the other way round
